awd_titl_txt: Remodeling of Pulmonary Cardiovascular Networks in the Presence of Hypertension
awd_abstract_narration:
The research team will develop mathematical and computational models for the study of pulmonary hypertension. This is a rare but rapidly progressing cardiovascular disease with a high mortality rate.  Pulmonary hypertension involves both elevated blood pressure and changes in vessel wall stiffness, and thickness within the pulmonary circulation. These issues worsen with the severity of the disease. Diagnostic disease categories are associated with different parts of the pulmonary circulation network, yet pinpointing locations where the disease initiates is challenging. Models will be developed in conjunction with the use of experimental data provided by collaborators. This data will be obtained from non-invasive imaging of vascular blood flow and vessel network structure, and from invasive measurements of blood pressure in pulmonary vessels in mice and humans obtained via catheterization.  Effects of the heart chambers, large vessels, small vessel networks and their interactions will be captured based on modeling and methodological approaches from fluid mechanics, solid mechanics, network analysis, inverse problems and parameter estimation. The proposed pulmonary cardiovascular model has potential to be incorporated into diagnostic protocols predicting pressure using non-invasive measurements to reduce the number of the invasive follow-up procedures, and to serve as a vital component for identifying signatures associated with disease diagnostic categories and the degree of disease progression.  The overall project also provides a variety of opportunities for integrated training of a postdoc, and graduate and undergraduate students, in data-driven biomedical research.

System-level, one-dimensional mathematical and computational fluid dynamics models of the pulmonary circulation will be developed. These models will include the right ventricle, left atrium, the large and small pulmonary arteries and veins, and account for alterations in the system components due to pulmonary hypertension. A physiologically based arterial and venous wall model that accounts for collagen and elastin content and that can also capture remodeling of wall constituents in response to pulmonary hypertension will be designed. This model will be rooted in nonlinear elasticity theory and will yield a more robust pressure-area relation that can be integrated within the  fluid dynamics model, and linearized to facilitate the transition from large to small vessels.  A second physiologically based right ventricle model combining ideas from simple elastance functions and single-fiber models will also be provided. This model will enable  prediction of elastance as a function of right ventricle thickness. The analysis will focus on the pulmonary circulation, but impacts on modeling systemic circulation in a comprehensive closed loop model will also be considered. The models developed in these two aims will be used to simulate and identify flow and pressure waveforms that predict features associated with disease progression and, via sensitivity analysis and parameter estimation, to render the model patient-specific.  With these innovations it will be possible to use the one dimensional system level model combined with pulmonary arterial blood pressure from non-invasive measurements of flow to assess disease progression associated with pulmonary hypertension while also reducing the number of invasive measurements.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit: We devised a pressure-area model based on  tissue mechanics. We developed the model from the Holzapfel-Gasser-Ogden (HGO) model, one of the most popular anisotropic hyperelastic models originally developed for anisotropic arteries, where the material is represented by families of collagen fibers embedded into an isotropic elastin extracellular matrix. The vessel wall is modeled as a thick-walled nonlinearly elastic circular cylindrical tube consisting of two layers, the media, and adventitia. The model is calibrated using ex-vivo measurements of vessel diameter and wall thickness changes, under controlled flow conditions, in left pulmonary arteries isolated from control and hypertensive mice. Sensitivity analysis, parameter estimation and subset selection are used to  reduce the 16-parameter model to one in which a small subset of identifiable parameters is estimated via solution of an inverse problem. Our final reduced model includes a single set of three elastic moduli. Estimated ranges of these parameters demonstrate that nonlinear stiffening is dominated by elastin in the control animals and by collagen in the hypertensive group. The novel pressure-area relation developed in this study has potential impact on one-dimensional (1D) fluids network models of vessel wall remodeling in the presence of cardiovascular disease. A manuscript disseminating results were submitted during this report period and results were presented at the World Congress of Biomechanics, July 2022.

To date, most models addressing pulmonary hypertension do not explicitly include capillaries, important as most subtypes start in these vessels. To remedy this, we devised a capillary model to be integrated with our 1D fluids network model. The capillaries facilitate oxygen transport to the lungs and throughout the pulmonary vasculature. They surround the pulmonary alveoli and have an irregular branching pattern that is dissimilar from the tube structure of the arterioles and venules. As first suggested by Fung, the dense capillary network can be approximated by a sheet of fluid flowing between two membranes. The flow through this sheet can be predicted as a function of sheet height, viscosity, filtration, and pressure. We have formulated a model that can be solved semi-analytically within each capillary. We set up a ladderlike structure in which one capillary sheet connects each arteriole segment to the corresponding venule segment. Future work will solve this model numerically, devising a true multiscale pulmonary vascular model. This work is included in a new NSF-EPSRC proposal submitted in December 2022. Results were presented at the Conference on Computational and Mathematical Biomedical Engineering in June 2022.

 

Broader Impacts: We have presented results at several conferences including the two listed above and in a plenary talk at the BAMM (Biology and Medicine Through Mathematics) by Olufsen (PI). Educational efforts include mentoring of four PhD students (3 female, 1 URM). Of these Olufsen (PI) and Haider (coPI) commentored one student (female). Two students graduated during this report period, and one defended her dissertation in December 2022. In addition, this award helped the PI Olufsen attract funding for the DRUMS REU program funded by NSF from 2020-2023 and from the NSA via three yearly awards (2021, 2022, 2023).  The project has also contributed to the development of local sensitivity-based identifiability analysis techniques for model reduction that have impacted several of Haider’s projects in data-driven mathematical modeling (presented at SIAM LS22).

Another significant broader impact is our continued collaboration with University of Glasgow, UK that has led to a new proposal submitted in December for the NSF-EPSCR program. This collaboration include students, postdocs, and faculty from both institutions. The group meets weekly via zoom discussing research progress and questions among all participants.  Another broader impact was a model used in the Cside Data science competition. We provided a model along with surrogate data; the students participating were asked to provide best inference scheme fitting the model to data.

Outcomes: A new multiscale patient-specific 1D fluid dynamics model for the prediction of CTEPH treatment and a new mechanics-based pressure-area model. CT data was used to construct large and small 3D networks. We predicted flow and pressure in 20 partially blocked vessels.  Using optimization, we determined what vessels to treat (widen) using pulmonary balloon angioplasty. Results have been published in more than 13 manuscripts (three in review) and 11 proceedings papers. Due to COVID, many of the presentations were remote, and we switched planned collaborative meetings to remote format. The award supported one postdoc (Umar Qureshi, currently a program director at Duke Health) and four graduate students (3 female and one URM). One student received a fellowship from American Heart Association, one received a GEM fellowship, and one is supported in part by an NIH grant, and one student (female, URM) received a GEM fellowship. Three students have graduated, one is a postdoc at UC Irvine, and two attracted jobs in data-science. In addition to training students, outcomes include successful collaboration with researchers and students at University of Glasgow.


Last Modified: 12/20/2022
Modified by: Mette S Olufsen
